result.markdown:
# Regression Models: Extensions After covering the basics of regression models, this chapter explores some useful extensions of regression models in R. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) dat1 <- data.frame(id = 1:8, var1 = c(2,1,2,5,7,8,9,5), var2 = c(2,2,1,9,7,4,25,3), educ = c(3,1,2,2,1,3,2,-1), gend = c(2,1,1,2,1,2,1,2), x = c(2,1,2,4,1,NA,NA,NA)) dat1$ed_fct <- factor(dat1$educ, levels = 1:3, labels = c("basic","medium","high")) dat1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct 1 1 2 2 3 2 2 high 2 2 1 2 1 1 1 basic 3 3 2 1 2 1 2 medium 4 4 5 9 2 2 4 medium 5 5 7 7 1 1 1 basic 6 6 8 4 3 2 NA high 7 7 9 25 2 1 NA medium 8 8 5 3 -1 2 NA ``` ::: ::: + [Complete rows with `complete.cases()`](#complcses) -> `e(sample)` in Stata + [Interactions](#inter) -> `c.var1##c.var2` in Stata + [Quadratic Terms](#quad) -> `c.var1##c.var1` in Stata + [Applying Weights](#gew) + [Robust Standard Errors](#rbst) + [Fixed Effects Models](#fe) + [Multilevel Models](#mlvl) ## Keeping Only Complete Rows {#complcses} When we compare models `m1` and `m3`, we see different sample sizes: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m1 <- lm(var2 ~ var1, data = dat1) m4 <- lm(var2 ~ ed_fct + var1, data = dat1) modelsummary(list("m1"=m1,"m4"=m4), gof_omit = "IC|RM|Log|F", output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

m1

m4

(Intercept)

-2.340

-2.511

(4.345)

(5.681)

var1

1.839

1.753

(0.773)

(0.835)

ed_fctmedium

4.830

(6.038)

ed_fcthigh

-3.253

(6.554)

Num.Obs.

8

7

R2

0.486

0.700

R2 Adj.

0.400

0.400

``` ::: ::: It appears that in model `m4`, one case is lost with `ed_fct`. Why is that? Itâ€™s worth taking a look at the data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct 1 1 2 2 3 2 2 high 2 2 1 2 1 1 1 basic 3 3 2 1 2 1 2 medium 4 4 5 9 2 2 4 medium 5 5 7 7 1 1 1 basic 6 6 8 4 3 2 NA high 7 7 9 25 2 1 NA medium 8 8 5 3 -1 2 NA ``` ::: ::: The value for `ed_fct` is missing for `id` = 8. To compare the models, we should use only the rows where `ed_fct` values are available. We can manually select these rows (excluding `id`=8), but this can be cumbersome with larger datasets. ### `complete.cases()` Here, `complete.cases()` is helpful. This function creates a logical variable that is `TRUE` for all complete cases (i.e., without `NA`). Incomplete cases are marked as `FALSE`. We specify which variables to consider for this check and add the variable to the dataset as a new column. For model 1, a case is considered `complete` if both `var2` and `var1` are present. So, we select the relevant variables with `select()` and apply `complete.cases` to this selection: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1 %>% select(var1, var2) %>% complete.cases(.) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dat1$compl_m1 <- dat1 %>% select(var1, var2) %>% complete.cases(.) dat1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct compl_m1 1 1 2 2 3 2 2 high TRUE 2 2 1 2 1 1 1 basic TRUE 3 3 2 1 2 1 2 medium TRUE 4 4 5 9 2 2 4 medium TRUE 5 5 7 7 1 1 1 basic TRUE 6 6 8 4 3 2 NA high TRUE 7 7 9 25 2 1 NA medium TRUE 8 8 5 3 -1 2 NA TRUE ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-warning collapse="true"} # `complete.cases()` alone searches for `NA` in all variables Note: if we do not specify variables, `NA` will be considered from all variables, including `x`, which we are not interested in here: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1 %>% complete.cases(.) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dat1$compl <- dat1 %>% complete.cases(.) dat1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct compl_m1 compl 1 1 2 2 3 2 2 high TRUE TRUE 2 2 1 2 1 1 1 basic TRUE TRUE 3 3 2 1 2 1 2 medium TRUE TRUE 4 4 5 9 2 2 4 medium TRUE TRUE 5 5 7 7 1 1 1 basic TRUE TRUE 6 6 8 4 3 2 NA high TRUE FALSE 7 7 9 25 2 1 NA medium TRUE FALSE 8 8 5 3 -1 2 NA TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: We do the same for model `m4`, which includes `ed_fct` in addition to `var2` and `var1`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1$compl_m4 <- dat1 %>% select(var1, var2, ed_fct) %>% complete.cases(.) ``` ::: Hereâ€™s how it looks in the dataset: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct compl_m1 compl_m4 1 1 2 2 3 2 2 high TRUE TRUE 2 2 1 2 1 1 1 basic TRUE TRUE 3 3 2 1 2 1 2 medium TRUE TRUE 4 4 5 9 2 2 4 medium TRUE TRUE 5 5 7 7 1 1 1 basic TRUE TRUE 6 6 8 4 3 2 NA high TRUE TRUE 7 7 9 25 2 1 NA medium TRUE TRUE 8 8 5 3 -1 2 NA TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: ### Finding Cases with Missing Values Now, we can filter by these variables and examine these cases more closely. We filter for cases that are included in `m1` (i.e., `compl_m1` = `TRUE`) but not in `m4` (`compl_m4` = `FALSE`): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1 %>% filter(compl_m1 == T & compl_m4 == F) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id var1 var2 educ gend x ed_fct compl_m1 compl_m4 1 8 5 3 -1 2 NA TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: ### Calculating Models with Only Complete Cases We can now create model `m1` to include only cases that are also considered in model `m4`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m1_m4vars <- lm(var2 ~ var1, data = filter(dat1, compl_m4 == T)) modelsummary(list("m1"=m1,"m1 with m4vars"=m1_m4vars,"m4"=m4), gof_omit = "IC|RM|Log|F", output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

m1

m1 with m4vars

m4

(4.345)

(4.646)

(5.681)

(0.814)

(0.835)

(6.554)

Num.Obs.

8

0.486

R2 Adj.

0.400

0.409

0.400

``` ::: ::: Now, both `m1 with m4vars` and `m4` have the same number of cases, allowing for a direct comparison of the results. ## Interactions {#inter} Interactions between two variables can be calculated using `*`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat1$g_fct <- factor(dat1$gend, levels = 1:2, labels = c("women","men")) m5 <- lm(var2 ~ var1 * g_fct, data = dat1) summary(m5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = var2 ~ var1 * g_fct, data = dat1) Residuals: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 -1.5000 2.6145 -0.8827 4.5000 -7.3687 -1.5000 5.6369 -1.5000 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) -3.1117 4.7702 -0.652 0.5498 var1 2.4972 0.8211 3.041 0.0384 * g_fctmen 5.9451 8.4973 0.700 0.5227 var1:g_fctmen -2.1639 1.5331 -1.411 0.2310 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 5.493 on 4 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.7244, Adjusted R-squared: 0.5177 F-statistic: 3.504 on 3 and 4 DF, p-value: 0.1286 ``` ::: ::: `avg_slopes()` from `{marginaleffects}` helps to calculate the marginal effects/slopes of a one-unit increase in `var1` for each subgroup of `g_fct`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} avg_slopes(m5, variables = "var1", by = "g_fct") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` g_fct Estimate Std. Error z Pr(>|z|) S 2.5 % 97.5 % women 2.497 0.821 3.041 0.00236 8.7 0.888 4.11 men 0.333 1.295 0.257 0.79684 0.3 -2.204 2.87 Term: var1 Type: response Comparison: mean(dY/dX) Columns: term, contrast, g_fct, estimate, std.error, statistic, p.value, s.value, conf.low, conf.high, predicted_lo, predicted_hi, predicted ``` ::: ::: Interactions should always be visualized. `plot_predictions()` from `{marginaleffects}` is a very helpful function to plot the predicted values : ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot_predictions(m5, condition = c("var1", "g_fct")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=80% height=60%} ::: ::: We can modify this plot using familiar `{ggplot2}` commands: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot_predictions(m5, condition = c("var1", "g_fct")) + scale_color_manual(values = c("orange","lightskyblue3"), breaks = c("women","men"), labels=c("Women","Men")) + scale_fill_manual(values = c("orange","lightskyblue3"), breaks = c("women","men"), labels=c("Women","Men")) + labs(title = "Predicted Values for var2", color = "Gender", fill = "Gender", x = "Values for var1", y = "Predicted Values for var1") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: **[Alternatively, we can create the "marginsplot" step by step ourselves](#marginsplot)** ## Quadratic Terms & Polynomials {#quad} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m6 <- lm(var2 ~ var1 + I(var1^2), data = dat1 %>% filter(id != 7)) summary(m6) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = var2 ~ var1 + I(var1^2), data = dat1 %>% filter(id != 7)) Residuals: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 -0.5443 1.4334 -1.5443 3.2043 1.2713 -1.0248 -2.7957 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) -1.8580 3.4066 -0.545 0.614 var1 2.6481 1.9083 1.388 0.238 I(var1^2) -0.2235 0.2110 -1.059 0.349 Residual standard error: 2.524 on 4 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.5099, Adjusted R-squared: 0.2648 F-statistic: 2.081 on 2 and 4 DF, p-value: 0.2402 ``` ::: ::: Again, `{marginaleffects}` provides a helpful function to visualize the shape of predicted values: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot_predictions(m6, condition = "var1") # conditional adjusted predictions ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=60% height=60%} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot_slopes(m6, variables = "var1", condition = "var1") # conditional marginal effects ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-2.png){width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ## Logistic regression model For binary dependent variables, logistic regression models are a widely used tool. We can fit logistic regression models in R using `glm()` - for an example, we turn to `PSM0100` (Usage of social networks yes = 2, no = 1) : \begin{equation*} \widehat{Logit(soc\_med=1)} = \widehat{ln\left(\frac{P(soc\_med=1)}{1-P(soc\_med=1)}\right)} = \hat\beta0 + \hat{\beta1}\times \texttt{palter} \end{equation*} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend10 <- haven::read_dta("./orig/PENDDAT_cf_W13.dta", col_select = c("palter","PSM0100")) %>% filter(PSM0100>0) %>% mutate(soc_med = 2- PSM0100) pend10 %>% count(soc_med,PSM0100) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 3 soc_med PSM0100 n 1 0 2 [No] 2873 2 1 1 [Yes] 2589 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} m2 <- glm(soc_med ~ palter, family = "binomial", data = pend10) summary(m2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = soc_med ~ palter, family = "binomial", data = pend10) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) 3.194321 0.107660 29.67 <2e-16 *** palter -0.073518 0.002315 -31.75 <2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 7557.2 on 5461 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 6217.5 on 5460 degrees of freedom AIC: 6221.5 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 3 ``` ::: ::: The interpretation of the $\beta$ coefficients from a logistic regression model pertains to the logits (the logarithms of the odds): *There is a statistically significant relationship at the 0.001 level between age and the likelihood of using social media. With each additional year of age, there is a decrease of 0.073518 in the *logits* of the respondents using social media.* ### average marginal effects Logits are quite cumbersomeâ€”so how does the *probability* of $\texttt{soc\_med} = 1$ change with `palter`? Here, we face the challenge that the derivative of the "inverse function" is not as straightforward as in the case of OLS. If we modify the [regression equation from above[^2]](#logmod) with `exp()` and $p=\frac{Odds}{1+Odds}$, we get: \begin{equation*} \widehat{P(soc\_med=1)} = \frac{e^{\hat\beta0+\hat\beta1 \times \texttt{palter}}}{1+e^{\hat\beta0+\hat{\beta1}\times \texttt{palter}}} \end{equation*} [^2]: $\widehat{Logit(soc\_med=1)} = \widehat{ln\left(\frac{P(soc\_med=1)}{1-P(soc\_med=1)}\right)} = \hat\beta0 + \hat{\beta1}\times \texttt{palter}$ We would need to differentiate this expression with respect to `palter` to determine how the predicted probability of $\texttt{soc\_med} = 1$ changes with each additional year of respondent age. Given that `palter` appears in both the exponent of the `e` function and both the numerator and denominator ("top and bottom"), the differentiation becomes significantly more complex than in the previous `lm()` models. For our purposes, it is crucial to note that to compute changes in the predicted probabilities, we need the so-called marginal effects from the `{marginaleffects}` package. This package includes the `avg_slopes()` function, which allows us to calculate a $\beta$ representing the change in the _probability_ of $\texttt{soc\_med} = 1$ in relation to `palter`. This is known as the *average marginal effect*, as it provides the *average* marginal change in the dependent variable for a one-unit increase in the independent variable. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fdz_install("marginaleffects") # nur einmal nÃ¶tig library(marginaleffects) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} avg_slopes(m2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Estimate Std. Error z Pr(>|z|) S 2.5 % 97.5 % -0.0142 0.000266 -53.4 <0.001 Inf -0.0147 -0.0137 Term: palter Type: response Comparison: mean(dY/dX) Columns: term, contrast, estimate, std.error, statistic, p.value, s.value, conf.low, conf.high, predicted_lo, predicted_hi, predicted ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: *With each additional year of age, there is on average a decrease of 0.01419 (1.419 percentage points) in the probability of using social media.* ## Weighted Regression Model {#gew} The `{survey}` package allows including weights when fitting regression model: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fdz_install("survey") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(survey) pend <- haven::read_dta("./orig/PENDDAT_cf_W13.dta") %>% filter(netges > 0 , palter > 0, azges1 > 0) %>% mutate(zpsex_fct = factor(zpsex, levels = 1:2, labels = c("M","W"))) wgt_df <- haven::read_dta("./orig/pweights_cf_W13.dta") pend_wgt <- pend %>% left_join(wgt_df, by = join_by(pnr,welle)) modx <- lm(netges ~ palter + I(palter^2),data=pend) pend_weighted <- svydesign(id = ~pnr, weights = ~wqp, data = pend_wgt) # family = gaussian() provides a linear regression model, like lm() - but weighted survey_modx <- svyglm(netges ~ palter + I(palter^2), family = gaussian(), data = etb18,design = pend_weighted) modelsummary(list("lm()"=modx,"svyglm()"= survey_modx),gof_omit = "RM|IC|Log",output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

lm()

svyglm()

``` ::: ::: ## "Robust" Standard Errors {#rbst} Often, standard errors need to be adjusted for violations of general assumptions (homoscedasticity, etc.). The good news is that R offers several ways to correct standard errors, including with [{sandwich}](http://sandwich.r-forge.r-project.org/articles/sandwich.html) or [{estimatr}](https://declaredesign.org/r/estimatr/articles/getting-started.html). A very simple option is the correction of standard errors in `{modelsummary}`, which we will look at in more detail: We can request *heteroskedasticity-consistent* (HC) "robust" standard errors with the `vcov` option `HC` in `modelsummary()`. The help page for `{modelsummary}` provides a [list of all options](https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/modelsummary/articles/modelsummary.html#vcov). One option is also `stata`, to replicate results from Stataâ€™s `, robust`. [More here](https://declaredesign.org/r/estimatr/articles/stata-wls-hat.html) about the background and differences. Based on [the data read above](#gew), we can estimate the following model: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mod1 <- lm(netges ~ palter + I(palter^2),data=pend) library(modelsummary) modelsummary(list(mod1,mod1,mod1,mod1),vcov = c("classical","HC","HC2","stata"),gof_omit = "RM|IC|Log",output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

+ p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001

``` ::: ::: ## Fixed Effects Models with `{fixest}` {#fe} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fdz_install("fixest") ``` ::: [`{fixest}`](https://lrberge.github.io/fixest)) offers a wide range of options: [logistic FE models](#10_log_reg.qmd##feglm), multi-dimensional fixed effects, multiway clustering, etc. And it is very fast, [e.g., faster](https://lrberge.github.io/fixest/#benchmarking) than Stataâ€™s `reghdfe`. For more details, the [vignette](https://lrberge.github.io/fixest/articles/fixest_walkthrough.html) is recommended. The central function for estimating linear FE regression models is `feols()` - it works very similarly to `lm()`. We provide a formula following the pattern `dependent variable ~ independent variable(s)`. We simply add the variable that specifies the FEs with `|`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(fixest) fe_mod1 <- feols(netges ~ palter + I(palter^2) | pnr, data = pend) fe_mod1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: netges Observations: 7,996 Fixed-effects: pnr: 2,444 Standard-errors: Clustered (pnr) Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) palter 133.811281 14.558248 9.19144 < 2.2e-16 *** I(palter^2) -0.848429 0.154417 -5.49441 4.3261e-08 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 RMSE: 1,222.2 Adj. R2: 0.513287 Within R2: 0.009765 ``` ::: ::: `{fixest}` automatically clusters the standard errors along the FE variable (here `pnr`). If we donâ€™t want that, we can request unclustered SEs with the `se` option `= "standard"`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(fe_mod1, se = 'standard') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: netges Observations: 7,996 Fixed-effects: pnr: 2,444 Standard-errors: IID Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) palter 133.811281 39.896986 3.35392 0.00080209 *** I(palter^2) -0.848429 0.429629 -1.97479 0.04834109 * --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 RMSE: 1,222.2 Adj. R2: 0.513287 Within R2: 0.009765 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(fe_mod1, cluster = ~pnr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: netges Observations: 7,996 Fixed-effects: pnr: 2,444 Standard-errors: Clustered (pnr) Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) palter 133.811281 14.558248 9.19144 < 2.2e-16 *** I(palter^2) -0.848429 0.154417 -5.49441 4.3261e-08 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 RMSE: 1,222.2 Adj. R2: 0.513287 Within R2: 0.009765 ``` ::: ::: `{modelsummary}` shows the clustered SEs: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} modelsummary(fe_mod1,gof_omit = "R|IC|Log|F",stars = T,output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

+ p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001

``` ::: ::: ## Multilevel Models with `{lme4}` {#mlvl} With `lmer()`, we can estimate a random intercept model by specifying `( 1 | pnr)`, which indicates that a separate random intercept should be calculated for each `pnr`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(lme4) ml_m3 <- lmer(netges ~ palter + I(palter^2) + ( 1 | pnr), data=pend) modelsummary(list(ml_m3),gof_omit = "R|IC|Log|F",output = "flextable") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

(1)

(Intercept)

754.388

(392.459)

palter

18.523

(19.083)

I(palter^2)

-0.020

(0.222)

SD (Intercept pnr)

1327.674

SD (Observations)

1414.455

Num.Obs.

7996

``` ::: ::: More about multilevel models and `{lme4}` in blog posts by [Rense Nieuwenhuis](http://www.rensenieuwenhuis.nl/r-sessions-16-multilevel-model-specification-lme4/) and [Tristan Mahr](https://www.tjmahr.com/plotting-partial-pooling-in-mixed-effects-models/). In the [Interactions](#interactions) chapter, we estimated the following model: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(m5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = var2 ~ var1 * g_fct, data = dat1) Residuals: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 -1.5000 2.6145 -0.8827 4.5000 -7.3687 -1.5000 5.6369 -1.5000 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) -3.1117 4.7702 -0.652 0.5498 var1 2.4972 0.8211 3.041 0.0384 * g_fctmen 5.9451 8.4973 0.700 0.5227 var1:g_fctmen -2.1639 1.5331 -1.411 0.2310 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 5.493 on 4 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.7244, Adjusted R-squared: 0.5177 F-statistic: 3.504 on 3 and 4 DF, p-value: 0.1286 ``` ::: ::: With `predictions()` from `{marginaleffects}`, we can calculate predicted values for specific values based on our model. We specify the desired values with a `datagrid()` - which automatically sets other variables to their mean: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create combinations of all values datagrid(var1 = 1:5, g_fct = c("women","men"),model = m5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` var1 g_fct rowid 1 1 women 1 2 1 men 2 3 2 women 3 4 2 men 4 5 3 women 5 6 3 men 6 7 4 women 7 8 4 men 8 9 5 women 9 10 5 men 10 ``` ::: ::: We then provide these values to `predictions()` as `newdata =`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(marginaleffects) p <- predictions(m5, newdata = datagrid(var1 = 1:5, g_fct = c("women","men"))) # ,model = m5 unnecessary since predictions are already specified: head(data.frame(p)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` rowid estimate std.error statistic p.value s.value conf.low conf.high 1 1 -0.6145251 4.126052 -0.1489378 0.8816027 0.1817994 -8.701438 7.472388 2 2 3.1666667 5.861938 0.5402082 0.5890535 0.7635295 -8.322520 14.655854 3 3 1.8826816 3.555532 0.5295076 0.5964533 0.7455188 -5.086034 8.851397 4 4 3.5000000 4.756978 0.7357612 0.4618760 1.1144224 -5.823506 12.823506 5 5 4.3798883 3.099641 1.4130307 0.1576467 2.6652332 -1.695297 10.455073 6 6 3.8333333 3.774624 1.0155536 0.3098420 1.6903954 -3.564794 11.231461 var1 g_fct var2 1 1 women 2 2 1 men 2 3 2 women 2 4 2 men 2 5 3 women 2 6 3 men 2 ``` ::: ::: For `ggplot()`, we use `geom_line()` together with + `geom_errorbar()` for a visualization with confidence intervals as error bars + `geom_ribbon()` for confidence intervals as shaded bands (here, we need to set the opacity with `alpha =` and specify the color with `fill=` to color the area). ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"} ```{.r .cell-code} pred_plt <- ggplot(data= data.frame(p), aes(x = var1, y = estimate, ymin = conf.low,ymax = conf.high, color = g_fct)) + geom_line() + scale_color_manual(values = c("orange","lightskyblue3"),breaks = c("women","men"),labels=c("Women","Men")) + labs(title = "Predicted Values for var2", color = "Gender", fill = "Gender", x = "Values for var1", y = "Predicted Values for var2") + theme_minimal() # Confidence intervals pred_plt + geom_point(size = 2.75) + geom_errorbar(width = .1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=3500} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # With confidence bands pred_plt + geom_ribbon(alpha = .1, color = NA,aes(fill = g_fct)) + scale_fill_manual(values = c("orange","lightskyblue3"),breaks = c("women","men"),labels=c("Women","Men")) + labs(title = "Predicted Values for var2", color = "Gender", fill = "Gender", x = "Values for var1", y = "Predicted Values for var2") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_reg2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-2.png){width=3500} ::: :::
